item.title: Joseph Conrad
item.description: Polish dude who was part of the minority and then became a British Citizen. He was a colonized and a colonizer.

item.title: Meena Alexander
item.description: Indian-American writer [[postcolonial]], [[diasporic]] themes: identity, diaspora, exile, uprooting, separation, displacement, postcolonialism, [[Illiterate Heart]]

item.title: Judith Butler
item.description: Judith Butler is an American academic whose theories of the performative nature of gender and sex were influential within Francocentric philosophy, cultural theory, queer theory, and some schools of philosophical feminism from the late 20th century.

item.title: Friedrich Nietzsche
item.description: Bio Name:: Friedrich Nietzsche Title:: ShortDesc:: German philosopher, poet, and philologist 1844 to 1900 known for his radical critique of Western civilization and morality, his concept of the will to power, his proclamation of the death of God, and his idea of the Übermensch (the superior human who creates his own values and meaning).

item.title: Daniel Kahneman
item.description: Israeli-American psychologist Nobel laureate pioneer of behavioral economics and judgment and decision making He collaborated with Amos Tversky to develop the prospect theory, which describes how people make choices under uncertainty and risk.

item.title: Noam Chomsky
item.description: American linguist and cognitive scientist regarded as the father of modern linguistics proposed that humans have an innate capacity for language acquisition that is governed by universal rules or principles.

item.title: John Stuart Mill
item.description: Helped establish [[private/inbox/unprocessed/Utilitarianism]] Wrote “[[Subjection Of Women]]” along with his wife Harriet Taylor Mill Advocated women suffrage and equal rights (?

item.title: Michel Foucault
item.description: talks about [[Power Dynamics]] French philosopher and historian who made significant contributions to the fields of philosophy, history, and social theory.

item.title: Samuel Johnson
item.description: Samuel Johnson Lexicographer, writer, novelist, dramatist, journalist helped make English more popular his dictionary is an important work [[../../../Lives of the Most Eminent English Poets]] or Lives of The Poets examines 52 poets and has short biographies and critiques on each.

item.title: Mary Wollstone Craft
item.description: English writer (18th century) Precursor to [[Feminism]] anti-monarchy pro-republic (27 April 1759 - 10 September 1797) Advocated social equality of women

item.title: Lee de Forest
item.description: inventor invented the first electronic device for controlling current flow; the three-element “Audion” triode vacuum tube in 1906 started the Electronic Age

item.title: Clay Shirky
item.description: Clay Shirky (born 1964) is an American writer, consultant and teacher on the social and economic effects of Internet technologies and journalism.

item.title: Robert Louis Stevenson
item.description: Scottish novelist, essayist, poet and travel writer known for Treasure Island; The Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde

item.title: Aaron T Beck
item.description: ![[images/Aaron T Beck.jpg|100]] Aaron T Beck (July 18, 1921 – November 1, 2021) - influential psychiatrist who is regarded as the father of cognitive therapy and cognitive behavioural therapy.

item.title: T.S. Eliot
item.description: Prominent author Wrote The Waste Land - known as the Bible of 20th Century one of the most important authors of 20th century Nobel laureate Modernism Wrote [[Preludes]]

item.title: WB Yeats
item.description: Irish poet - Irish Nationalist Symbolist Inspired by Pre-Raphaelites and William Blake poetry was a reaction to the naturalistic and realistic poetry of the Victorian age
